TEXT.English: [TAB]The Maratha are an Indian warrior caste native to Maharashtra. Prior to the rise of Shivaji Maharaj and the Maratha Empire (17th c.), members of the caste served primarily as mercenaries to Muslim rulers of the Deccan plateau and Gujarat. Maratha warriors are famed for their use of pata, a sword with a gauntlet integrated as a handguard.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Maratha are an Indian warrior caste native to Maharashtra. Prior to the rise of Shivaji Maharaj and the Maratha Empire (17th c.), members of the caste served primarily as mercenaries to Muslim rulers of the Deccan plateau and Gujarat. Maratha warriors are famed for their use of pata, a sword with a gauntlet integrated as a handguard.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Maratha sind eine indische Kriegerkaste, die in Maharashtra beheimatet ist. Vor dem Aufstieg von Shivaji Maharaj und dem Maratha-Reich (17. Jh.) dienten Mitglieder der Kaste hauptsächlich als Söldner für muslimische Herrscher des Deccan-Plateaus und von Gujarat. Maratha-Krieger sind berühmt für ihre Verwendung von Pata, einem Schwert mit integriertem Handschuh als Handschutz.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Kshatriya meaning warrior is one of the four varnas (social orders) in Hinduism. It traditionally constituted the military and ruling elite of the Vedic-Hindu social system outlined by the Vedas and the Laws of Manu.[PARAGRAPH:1]Initially in ancient Vedic society, this position was achieved on the merits of a person's aptitude, conduct, and nature. The earliest Vedic literature listed by organization of function, not of caste, the Kshatriya (holders of kshatra, or authority) as first in rank, and the Brahmins second (priests and teachers of law), before the Vaisya (merchant-traders, farmers and some artisan castes), and the Sudra (labourers, some farming castes and other artisan castes). Movements of individuals and groups from one class to another, both upward and downward, were not uncommon; a rise in status even to the rank of Kshatriya was a recognized reward for outstanding service to the rulers of the day. Over the years it became hereditary. In modern times, the Kshatriya varna includes a broad class of caste groups, differing considerably in status and function but united by their claims to ruler-ship, the pursuit of war, or the possession of land. [PARAGRAPH:1]Western India remained a stronghold of Kshatriya clans as epitomized by Rajputana and the powerful Kshatriya empire that ruled from Ujjain right up to the Islamic incursions led to a downfall of the Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi.

Over the years it became hereditary. In modern times, the Kshatriya varna includes a broad class of caste groups, differing considerably in status and function but united by their claims to ruler-ship, the pursuit of war, or the possession of land. [PARAGRAPH:1]Western India remained a stronghold of Kshatriya clans as epitomized by Rajputana and the powerful Kshatriya empire that ruled from Ujjain right up to the Islamic incursions led to a downfall of the Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kshatriya bedeutet Krieger und ist eine der vier Varnas (Gesellschaftsordnungen) im Hinduismus. Sie bildete traditionell die militärische und herrschende Elite des vedisch-hinduistischen Gesellschaftssystems, das in den Veden und den Gesetzen des Manu dargelegt wird.[PARAGRAPH:1]Anfangs wurde diese Position in der alten vedischen Gesellschaft auf der Grundlage der Fähigkeiten, des Verhaltens und der Fähigkeiten einer Person erreicht. und Natur. In der frühesten vedischen Literatur sind die Kshatriya (Inhaber von Kshatra oder Autorität) nach Funktionsorganisation und nicht nach Kaste an erster Stelle und die Brahmanen an zweiter Stelle (Priester und Rechtslehrer) aufgeführt, vor den Vaisya (Kaufleute, Bauern). und einige Handwerkerkasten) und die Sudra (Arbeiter, einige Bauernkasten und andere Handwerkerkasten). Bewegungen von Einzelpersonen und Gruppen von einer Klasse zur anderen, sowohl nach oben als auch nach unten, waren keine Seltenheit; Eine Erhöhung des Status bis hin zum Rang eines Kshatriya war eine anerkannte Belohnung für herausragende Verdienste um die damaligen Herrscher. Im Laufe der Jahre wurde es erblich. In der Neuzeit umfasst die Kshatriya varna eine breite Klasse von Kastengruppen, die sich in Status und Funktion erheblich unterscheiden, aber durch ihren Anspruch auf Herrschaft, Krieg oder Landbesitz vereint sind. [PARAGRAPH:1]Westindien blieb eine Hochburg der Kshatriya-Clans, wie sie Rajputana verkörperte, und das mächtige Kshatriya-Reich, das von Ujjain aus herrschte, bis zu den islamischen Einfällen, die zum Sturz der Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi führten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Pathan is the Urdu/Hindu word for Pasthun, or Afghan. Since the Ghorid invasion in the 12th century, many Afghans settled in Northern India, and by 15th century they were considered natives, and produced two ruling dynasties (Lodi and Suri). [TAB]Apart from serving in the army of Delhi Sultanate and Sur Empire, Pathans fought as mercenaries. They were employed by Muslims, Hindus and Sikhs alike.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Pathan is the Urdu/Hindu word for Pasthun, or Afghan. Since the Ghorid invasion in the 12th century, many Afghans settled in Northern India, and by 15th century they were considered natives, and produced two ruling dynasties (Lodi and Suri). [TAB]Apart from serving in the army of Delhi Sultanate and Sur Empire, Pathans fought as mercenaries. They were employed by Muslims, Hindus and Sikhs alike.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Pathan ist das Urdu/Hindu-Wort für Pasthune oder Afghane. Seit der Invasion der Ghoriden im 12. Jahrhundert ließen sich viele Afghanen in Nordindien nieder, galten im 15. Jahrhundert als Einheimische und brachten zwei herrschende Dynastien hervor (Lodi und Suri). [TAB]Pathans dienten nicht nur in der Armee des Sultanats Delhi und des Sur-Reiches, sondern kämpften auch als Söldner. Sie wurden von Muslimen, Hindus und Sikhs gleichermaßen beschäftigt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Zanj ("Land of the Blacks") was a name used by medieval Arab geographers to refer to both a certain portion of the coast of East Africa and its inhabitants. Zanjis in Arabia were kept as slaves but also hired as mercenaries, notably by the Fatimid Caliphate in Egypt, whose armies included large numbers of Sudanese, Somali and Nubian soldiers.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Zanj ("Land of the Blacks") was a name used by medieval Arab geographers to refer to both a certain portion of the coast of East Africa and its inhabitants. Zanjis in Arabia were kept as slaves but also hired as mercenaries, notably by the Fatimid Caliphate in Egypt, whose armies included large numbers of Sudanese, Somali and Nubian soldiers.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Zanj ("Land der Schwarzen") war ein Name, der von mittelalterlichen arabischen Geographen verwendet wurde, um sowohl einen bestimmten Teil der Küste Ostafrikas als auch seine Bewohner zu bezeichnen. Zanjis in Arabien wurden als Sklaven gehalten, aber auch als Söldner angeheuert, insbesondere vom Fatimiden-Kalifat in Ägypten, zu dessen Armeen eine große Zahl sudanesischer, somalischer und nubischer Soldaten gehörte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Siphonarios is a specialist trained in the handling of a siphon - a tube used to project Greek fire onto enemies. [PARAGRAPH:1]Greek fire was an incendiary weapon used by the Byzantine Empire, typically in naval battles as it could continue burning even on water. It provided a technological advantage, and was responsible for many key Byzantine military victories, most notably the salvation of Constantinople from two Arab sieges, thus securing the Empire's survival.[PARAGRAPH:1]The portable cheirosiphon ("hand-siphon"), the earliest analogue to a modern flamethrower, is extensively attested in the military documents of the 10th century, and recommended for use in both sea and land. They first appear in the Tactica of emperor Leo VI the Wise, who claims to have invented them. Subsequent authors continued to refer to the cheirosiphones, especially for use against siege towers, although Nikephoros II Phokas also advises their use in field armies, with the aim of disrupting the enemy formation.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Siphonarios is a specialist trained in the handling of a siphon - a tube used to project Greek fire onto enemies. [PARAGRAPH:1]Greek fire was an incendiary weapon used by the Byzantine Empire, typically in naval battles as it could continue burning even on water. It provided a technological advantage, and was responsible for many key Byzantine military victories, most notably the salvation of Constantinople from two Arab sieges, thus securing the Empire's survival.[PARAGRAPH:1]The portable cheirosiphon ("hand-siphon"), the earliest analogue to a modern flamethrower, is extensively attested in the military documents of the 10th century, and recommended for use in both sea and land. They first appear in the Tactica of emperor Leo VI the Wise, who claims to have invented them. Subsequent authors continued to refer to the cheirosiphones, especially for use against siege towers, although Nikephoros II Phokas also advises their use in field armies, with the aim of disrupting the enemy formation.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Siphonarios ist ein Spezialist, der im Umgang mit einem Siphon ausgebildet ist - einem Rohr, mit dem griechisches Feuer auf Feinde projiziert wird. [PARAGRAPH:1]Griechisches Feuer war eine Brandwaffe, die vom Byzantinischen Reich typischerweise in Seeschlachten eingesetzt wurde, da es sogar auf dem Wasser weiter brennen konnte. Es bot einen technologischen Vorteil und war für viele wichtige byzantinische Militärsiege verantwortlich, insbesondere für die Rettung Konstantinopels vor zwei arabischen Belagerungen, und sicherte so das Überleben des Imperiums.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das tragbare Cheirosiphon ("Handsiphon"), das Das früheste Analogon zu einem modernen Flammenwerfer ist ausführlich in den Militärdokumenten des 10. Jahrhunderts bezeugt und wird für den Einsatz sowohl auf See als auch an Land empfohlen. Sie erscheinen erstmals in der Tactica von Kaiser Leo VI., dem Weisen, der behauptet, sie erfunden zu haben. Nachfolgende Autoren verwiesen weiterhin auf die Cheirosiphone, insbesondere für den Einsatz gegen Belagerungstürme, obwohl Nikephoros II. Phokas auch ihren Einsatz in Feldarmeen empfiehlt, mit dem Ziel, die feindliche Formation zu stören.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Paulicians were a heretical group within Orthodox Christianity. They flourished between 650 and 872 in Armenia and the Eastern Themes of the Byzantine Empire, where they were often persecuted.[PARAGRAPH:1]Many Paulician Armenians found refuge in the then tolerant Fatimid Egypt. There, they lived in relative prosperity, and Fatimids would often employ them as irregular troops.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Paulizier waren eine ketzerische Gruppe innerhalb des orthodoxen Christentums. Sie blühten zwischen 650 und 872 in Armenien und in den Ostthemen des Byzantinischen Reiches auf, wo sie oft verfolgt wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1]Viele paulizische Armenier fanden Zuflucht im damals toleranten fatimidischen Ägypten. Dort lebten sie in relativem Wohlstand und wurden von den Fatimiden oft als irreguläre Truppen eingesetzt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Abid al-Shira, or 'purchased slaves', were the lowest rank slave troops used by the Fatimid Caliphate. They were brought from Nubia and Sudan and fought as archers or light infantry.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Abid al-Shira, or 'purchased slaves', were the lowest rank slave troops used by the Fatimid Caliphate. They were brought from Nubia and Sudan and fought as archers or light infantry.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Abid al-Shira, oder "gekaufte Sklaven", waren die Sklaventruppen mit dem niedrigsten Rang, die vom Fatimiden-Kalifat eingesetzt wurden. Sie wurden aus Nubien und dem Sudan mitgebracht und kämpften als Bogenschützen oder leichte Infanterie.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Dihgan is an old name for Tajik, literally meaning "settled down". Tajiks are Persian-speaking Iranian inhabitants of Greater Khorasan (modern-day Tajikistan and Uzbekistan) and Afghanistan. Samanid Empire is considered to be the first Tajik state.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Dihgan is an old name for Tajik, literally meaning "settled down". Tajiks are Persian-speaking Iranian inhabitants of Greater Khorasan (modern-day Tajikistan and Uzbekistan) and Afghanistan. Samanid Empire is considered to be the first Tajik state.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Dihgan ist ein alter Name für die Tadschiken und bedeutet wörtlich "sesshaft". Tadschiken sind persischsprachige iranische Einwohner des Großraums Khorasan (heutiges Tadschikistan und Usbekistan) und Afghanistans. Das Samanidenreich gilt als der erste tadschikische Staat.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Bulgaria emerged as Byzantium's chief antagonist in the Balkans, resulting in several wars. The two powers however also enjoyed periods of peace and alliance, most notably during the Second Arab siege of Constantinople, where the Bulgarian army played a crucial role in breaking the siege.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Bulgaria emerged as Byzantium's chief antagonist in the Balkans, resulting in several wars. The two powers however also enjoyed periods of peace and alliance, most notably during the Second Arab siege of Constantinople, where the Bulgarian army played a crucial role in breaking the siege.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Bulgarien wurde zum Hauptgegner von Byzanz auf dem Balkan, was zu mehreren Kriegen führte. Die beiden Mächte erlebten jedoch auch Zeiten des Friedens und der Allianz, insbesondere während der zweiten arabischen Belagerung von Konstantinopel, bei der die bulgarische Armee eine entscheidende Rolle bei der Durchbrechung der Belagerung spielte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In addition to excellent cavalry, Timur's army relied skilled siege engineers. Timur is known to have used siege towers, bridges, trebuchets, fire pots, mining, as well as custom strategies such as diverting rivers.
TEXT.French: [TAB]In addition to excellent cavalry, Timur's army relied skilled siege engineers. Timur is known to have used siege towers, bridges, trebuchets, fire pots, mining, as well as custom strategies such as diverting rivers.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Zusätzlich zur hervorragenden Kavallerie stützte sich Timurs Armee auf erfahrene Belagerungsingenieure. Es ist bekannt, dass Timur Belagerungstürme, Brücken, Triboke, Feuertöpfe, Minen sowie maßgeschneiderte Strategien wie die Umleitung von Flüssen eingesetzt hat.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sailors from Maghreb and al-Andalus, armed with a crossbow, or Frankish bow, as it was called by the Arabs.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Seeleute aus dem Maghreb und al-Andalus, bewaffnet mit einer Armbrust oder einem fränkischen Bogen, wie die Araber ihn nannten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Abna were the Caliph's best men, the descendants of the original Abbasid army that settled in Baghdad.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Abna waren die besten Männer des Kalifen, die Nachkommen der ursprünglichen abbasidischen Armee, die sich in Bagdad niederließ.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Pashtuns are the dominant ethnic group of Afghanistan. Inhabiting the region since Achaemenid times, they have organized themselves into numerous tribes that engaged in constant warfare with each other, and with many invaders that sought to conquer Afghanistan and surrounding areas.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Pashtuns are the dominant ethnic group of Afghanistan. Inhabiting the region since Achaemenid times, they have organized themselves into numerous tribes that engaged in constant warfare with each other, and with many invaders that sought to conquer Afghanistan and surrounding areas.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Paschtunen sind die dominierende ethnische Gruppe Afghanistans. Sie bewohnten die Region seit der Zeit der Achämeniden und organisierten sich in zahlreichen Stämmen, die ständig Krieg untereinander und mit vielen Eindringlingen führten, die Afghanistan und die umliegenden Gebiete erobern wollten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sheikh is a word or honorific term in the Arabic language that literally means "elder". It is commonly used to designate an elder of a tribe, a revered wise man, or an Islamic scholar. Although the title generally refers to a male, a very small number of female sheikhs have also existed in history.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Sheikh is a word or honorific term in the Arabic language that literally means "elder". It is commonly used to designate an elder of a tribe, a revered wise man, or an Islamic scholar. Although the title generally refers to a male, a very small number of female sheikhs have also existed in history.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Scheich ist ein Wort oder Ehrenbegriff in der arabischen Sprache, der wörtlich "Ältester" bedeutet. Es wird üblicherweise zur Bezeichnung eines Stammesältesten, eines verehrten Weisen oder eines islamischen Gelehrten verwendet. Obwohl sich der Titel im Allgemeinen auf einen Mann bezieht, gab es in der Geschichte auch eine sehr kleine Anzahl weiblicher Scheichs.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Sheikh is a word or honorific term in the Arabic language that literally means "elder". It is commonly used to designate an elder of a tribe, a revered wise man, or an Islamic scholar. Although the title generally refers to a male, a very small number of female sheikhs have also existed in history.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In ancient times the camels were domesticated by various nomad tribes in Asia. When nomads began to invade the Middle East, the camel rider came to play an important military role. With the rise of Islam, Bedouins mounted on camels were important cavalry against the Persian and Byzantine armies. Camels continued to play a role in warfare throughout all of the Middle Ages.
TEXT.French: [TAB]In ancient times the camels were domesticated by various nomad tribes in Asia. When nomads began to invade the Middle East, the camel rider came to play an important military role. With the rise of Islam, Bedouins mounted on camels were important cavalry against the Persian and Byzantine armies. Camels continued to play a role in warfare throughout all of the Middle Ages.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In der Antike wurden Kamele von verschiedenen Nomadenstämmen in Asien domestiziert. Als Nomaden begannen, in den Nahen Osten einzudringen, spielte der Kamelreiter eine wichtige militärische Rolle. Mit dem Aufkommen des Islam waren Beduinen auf Kamelen eine wichtige Kavallerie gegen die persischen und byzantinischen Armeen. Kamele spielten im gesamten Mittelalter weiterhin eine Rolle in der Kriegsführung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In ancient times the camels were domesticated by various nomad tribes in Asia. When nomads began to invade the Middle East, the camel rider came to play an important military role. With the rise of Islam, Bedouins mounted on camels were important cavalry against the Persian and Byzantine armies. Camels continued to play a role in warfare throughout all of the Middle Ages.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]In ancient times the camels were domesticated by various nomad tribes in Asia. When nomads began to invade the Middle East, the camel rider came to play an important military role. With the rise of Islam, Bedouins mounted on camels were important cavalry against the Persian and Byzantine armies. Camels continued to play a role in warfare throughout all of the Middle Ages.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Pakistan and India, a Jagir was a small territory granted by the ruler to an army chieftain in fairly short terms usually of three years but not extending beyond his lifetime, in recognition of his military service. The grantee of the jagir, called a Jagirdar, was in effect the ruler of that region and substantial income that was earned (taxes, etc.) from this region went to the owner to maintain his family and his troops.
TEXT.French: [TAB]In Pakistan and India, a Jagir was a small territory granted by the ruler to an army chieftain in fairly short terms usually of three years but not extending beyond his lifetime, in recognition of his military service. The grantee of the jagir, called a Jagirdar, was in effect the ruler of that region and substantial income that was earned (taxes, etc.) from this region went to the owner to maintain his family and his troops.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In Pakistan und Indien war ein Jagir ein kleines Territorium, das der Herrscher einem Armeehäuptling in relativ kurzer Zeit, in der Regel von drei Jahren, jedoch nicht über seine Lebenszeit hinaus, als Anerkennung für seinen Militärdienst überließ. Der Berechtigte des Jagir, genannt Jagirdar, war praktisch der Herrscher dieser Region, und erhebliche Einnahmen (Steuern usw.) aus dieser Region gingen an den Besitzer, um seine Familie und seine Truppen zu ernähren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In Pakistan and India, a Jagir was a small territory granted by the ruler to an army chieftain in fairly short terms usually of three years but not extending beyond his lifetime, in recognition of his military service. The grantee of the jagir, called a Jagirdar, was in effect the ruler of that region and substantial income that was earned (taxes, etc.) from this region went to the owner to maintain his family and his troops.

The grantee of the jagir, called a Jagirdar, was in effect the ruler of that region and substantial income that was earned (taxes, etc.) from this region went to the owner to maintain his family and his troops.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Monaspa were the elite cavalrymen of the medieval Georgian Kingdom, composed of feudal lords as well as freemen.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Monaspa were the elite cavalrymen of the medieval Georgian Kingdom, composed of feudal lords as well as freemen.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Monaspa waren die Elitekavalleristen des mittelalterlichen georgischen Königreichs, bestehend aus Feudalherren und Freien.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ghazi or ghazah is an Arabic term that means "to raid." The term dates to at least the Samanid period, where he appears as a mercenary and frontier fighter in Khorasan and Transoxiana. Later, up to 20,000 of them took part in the Indian campaigns of Mahmud of Ghazni. Ghazi warriors depended upon plunder for their livelihood, and were prone to brigandage and sedition in times of peace. The corporations into which they organized themselves attracted adventurers, zealots and religious and political dissidents of all ethnicities. In time, though, soldiers of Turkic ethnicity predominated, mirroring the acquisition of Mamluks, Turkic slaves in the Mamluk retinues and guard corps of the caliphs and emirs and in the ranks of the ghazi corporation, some of whom would ultimately rise to military and later political dominance in various Muslim states.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the west, Turkic ghazis made continual incursions along the Byzantine frontier zone, finding in the akritai their Greek and Armenian counterparts. After the Battle of Manzikert these incursions intensified, and the region's people would see the ghazi corporations coalesce into semi-chivalric fraternities, with the white cap and the club as their emblems. The height of the organizations would come during the Mongol conquest when many of them fled from Persia and Turkistan into Anatolia.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Ghazi or ghazah is an Arabic term that means "to raid." The term dates to at least the Samanid period, where he appears as a mercenary and frontier fighter in Khorasan and Transoxiana. Later, up to 20,000 of them took part in the Indian campaigns of Mahmud of Ghazni. Ghazi warriors depended upon plunder for their livelihood, and were prone to brigandage and sedition in times of peace. The corporations into which they organized themselves attracted adventurers, zealots and religious and political dissidents of all ethnicities. In time, though, soldiers of Turkic ethnicity predominated, mirroring the acquisition of Mamluks, Turkic slaves in the Mamluk retinues and guard corps of the caliphs and emirs and in the ranks of the ghazi corporation, some of whom would ultimately rise to military and later political dominance in various Muslim states.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the west, Turkic ghazis made continual incursions along the Byzantine frontier zone, finding in the akritai their Greek and Armenian counterparts. After the Battle of Manzikert these incursions intensified, and the region's people would see the ghazi corporations coalesce into semi-chivalric fraternities, with the white cap and the club as their emblems. The height of the organizations would come during the Mongol conquest when many of them fled from Persia and Turkistan into Anatolia.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ghazi oder Ghazah ist ein arabischer Begriff, der "überfallen" bedeutet. Der Begriff reicht mindestens bis in die Zeit der Samaniden zurück, wo er als Söldner und Grenzkämpfer in Khorasan und Transoxiana auftritt. Später nahmen bis zu 20.000 von ihnen an den Indianerzügen von Mahmud von Ghazni teil. Ghazi-Krieger waren für ihren Lebensunterhalt auf Plünderung angewiesen und waren in Friedenszeiten anfällig für Räubertum und Aufruhr. Die Konzerne, in denen sie sich organisierten, zogen Abenteurer, Eiferer sowie religiöse und politische Dissidenten aller Ethnien an. Mit der Zeit überwogen jedoch Soldaten türkischer Abstammung, was sich in der Übernahme von Mamelucken, türkischen Sklaven, in den mamlukischen Gefolgsleuten und Wachkorps der Kalifen und Emire sowie in den Reihen der Ghazi-Corporation widerspiegelte, von denen einige schließlich zum Militär aufstiegen politische Dominanz in verschiedenen muslimischen Staaten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Westen unternahmen türkische Gazis kontinuierliche Einfälle entlang der byzantinischen Grenzzone und fanden in den Akritai ihre griechischen und armenischen Gegenstücke. Nach der Schlacht von Manzikert verstärkten sich diese Einfälle, und die Menschen in der Region erlebten, wie sich die Ghazi-Korporationen zu halbritterlichen Bruderschaften zusammenschlossen, deren Embleme die weiße Mütze und die Keule waren. Der Höhepunkt der Organisationen sollte während der Eroberung durch die Mongolen erreicht werden, als viele von ihnen aus Persien und Turkistan nach Anatolien flohen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original meaning of 'Turkoman' was any person of the many Turkic tribes that spread throughout Central Asia and the Middle East. Turkomans' lifestyle was always heavily invested in horsemanship, and their mastery of mounted warfare was second only to that of the Mongols.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The original meaning of 'Turkoman' was any person of the many Turkic tribes that spread throughout Central Asia and the Middle East. Turkomans' lifestyle was always heavily invested in horsemanship, and their mastery of mounted warfare was second only to that of the Mongols.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die ursprüngliche Bedeutung von "Turkomane" war jede Person aus den vielen Turkstämmen, die sich in Zentralasien und im Nahen Osten verbreiteten. Der Lebensstil der Turkmenen war schon immer stark von der Reitkunst geprägt, und ihre Beherrschung der berittenen Kriegsführung war nur der der Mongolen überlegen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The original meaning of 'Turkoman' was any person of the many Turkic tribes that spread throughout Central Asia and the Middle East. Turkomans' lifestyle was always heavily invested in horsemanship, and their mastery of mounted warfare was second only to that of the Mongols.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Daylamites were Iranian people inhabiting the mountainous regions of northern Iran on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. They were employed as soldiers from the time of the Sassanid Empire, and long resisted the Arab conquest of Iran and subsequent Islamization.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Daylamites were Iranian people inhabiting the mountainous regions of northern Iran on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. They were employed as soldiers from the time of the Sassanid Empire, and long resisted the Arab conquest of Iran and subsequent Islamization.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Dailamiten waren ein iranisches Volk, das in den Bergregionen im Norden Irans an der Südküste des Kaspischen Meeres lebte. Sie wurden seit der Zeit des Sassanidenreichs als Soldaten eingesetzt und leisteten lange Zeit Widerstand gegen die arabische Eroberung Irans und die anschließende Islamisierung.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Daylamites were Iranian people inhabiting the mountainous regions of northern Iran on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. They were employed as soldiers from the time of the Sassanid Empire, and long resisted the Arab conquest of Iran and subsequent Islamization.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The situation of peasants in the Byzantine Empire and Caucasian kingdoms was certainly better than in feudal Europe, but that does not mean the peasants would always agree with their rulers decisions, especially those pertaining high taxes and wars.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The situation of peasants in the Byzantine Empire and Caucasian kingdoms was certainly better than in feudal Europe, but that does not mean the peasants would always agree with their rulers decisions, especially those pertaining high taxes and wars.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Situation der Bauern im Byzantinischen Reich und in den kaukasischen Königreichen war sicherlich besser als im feudalen Europa, aber das bedeutet nicht, dass die Bauern immer mit den Entscheidungen ihrer Herrscher einverstanden waren, insbesondere wenn es um hohe Steuern und Kriege ging.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Qizilbash ("Crimson/Red Heads") is the label given to a wide variety of Shia Islamic militant groups that flourished in Anatolia and Kurdistan from the late 13th century onwards, some of which contributed to the foundation of the Safavid dynasty of Iran. The expression "Red Heads" is derived from their distinctive twelve gored crimson headwear, indicating their adherence to the twelve Ithna'ashari Imams and to Haydar Safavi, the spiritual leader (sheikh) of the Safaviyya movement. The Qizilbash were a coalition of many different peoples of predominantly (but not exclusively) Turkic-speaking Azerbaijani background, united in their adherence to the Safavid doctrine of Shiism.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Qizilbash ("Crimson/Red Heads") is the label given to a wide variety of Shia Islamic militant groups that flourished in Anatolia and Kurdistan from the late 13th century onwards, some of which contributed to the foundation of the Safavid dynasty of Iran. The expression "Red Heads" is derived from their distinctive twelve gored crimson headwear, indicating their adherence to the twelve Ithna'ashari Imams and to Haydar Safavi, the spiritual leader (sheikh) of the Safaviyya movement. The Qizilbash were a coalition of many different peoples of predominantly (but not exclusively) Turkic-speaking Azerbaijani background, united in their adherence to the Safavid doctrine of Shiism.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Qizilbash ("Karmesinrote/ Rothaarige") ist die Bezeichnung für eine Vielzahl schiitisch-islamischer militanter Gruppen, die ab dem späten 13. Jahrhundert in Anatolien und Kurdistan florierten und von denen einige zur Gründung der Safawiden-Dynastie beitrugen Iran. Der Ausdruck "Rotköpfe" leitet sich von ihrer charakteristischen purpurroten Kopfbedeckung mit zwölf Goren ab, die auf ihre Zugehörigkeit zu den zwölf Ithna'ashari-Imamen und zu Haydar Safavi, dem spirituellen Führer (Scheich) der Safaviyya-Bewegung, hinweist. Die Qizilbash waren eine Koalition vieler verschiedener Völker mit überwiegend (aber nicht ausschließlich) türkischsprachigem aserbaidschanischem Hintergrund, die sich in ihrem Festhalten an der safawidischen Doktrin des Schiismus einig waren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Qizilbash ("Crimson/Red Heads") is the label given to a wide variety of Shia Islamic militant groups that flourished in Anatolia and Kurdistan from the late 13th century onwards, some of which contributed to the foundation of the Safavid dynasty of Iran. The expression "Red Heads" is derived from their distinctive twelve gored crimson headwear, indicating their adherence to the twelve Ithna'ashari Imams and to Haydar Safavi, the spiritual leader (sheikh) of the Safaviyya movement. The Qizilbash were a coalition of many different peoples of predominantly (but not exclusively) Turkic-speaking Azerbaijani background, united in their adherence to the Safavid doctrine of Shiism.

TEXT.English: [TAB]There were many Venetian, Genoan and Pisan sailors, merchants and adventurers settled in the Levant. With their inferior training and equipment they are no match for professional military, but can become useful when organized into militia to protect their Levantine communes.
TEXT.French: [TAB]There were many Venetian, Genoan and Pisan sailors, merchants and adventurers settled in the Levant. With their inferior training and equipment they are no match for professional military, but can become useful when organized into militia to protect their Levantine communes.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In der Levante ließen sich viele venezianische, genuesische und pisanische Seeleute, Kaufleute und Abenteurer nieder. Mit ihrer minderwertigen Ausbildung und Ausrüstung sind sie dem professionellen Militär nicht gewachsen, können aber nützlich sein, wenn sie in Milizen organisiert werden, um ihre levantinischen Gemeinden zu schützen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Siege Elephant is a war elephant with a swivel gun or small cannon mounted on top. While not particularly effective as artillery, it can certainly be intimidating!

TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Belagerungselefant ist ein Kriegselefant mit einer drehbaren Kanone oder einer kleinen Kanone auf der Oberseite. Als Artillerie ist sie zwar nicht besonders effektiv, kann aber durchaus einschüchternd wirken!

TEXT.English: [TAB]A dhow is a traditional Arab sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used to carry heavy cargo along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, India and East Africa. Larger dhows have crews of approximately thirty people, while smaller dhows typically have crews of around twelve.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A dhow is a traditional Arab sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used to carry heavy cargo along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, India and East Africa. Larger dhows have crews of approximately thirty people, while smaller dhows typically have crews of around twelve.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Dau ist ein traditionelles arabisches Segelschiff mit einem oder mehreren lateinischen Segeln. Es dient vor allem dem Transport schwerer Güter entlang der Küsten der Arabischen Halbinsel, Pakistans, Indiens und Ostafrikas. Größere Dhaus haben eine Besatzung von etwa dreißig Personen, während kleinere Dhaus typischerweise eine Besatzung von etwa zwölf Personen haben.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]A dhow is a traditional Arab sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used to carry heavy cargo along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, India and East Africa. Larger dhows have crews of approximately thirty people, while smaller dhows typically have crews of around twelve.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A dhow is a traditional Arab sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used to carry heavy cargo along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Pakistan, India and East Africa. Larger dhows have crews of approximately thirty people, while smaller dhows typically have crews of around twelve.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A baghlah is a large deep-sea dhow, a traditional Arabic sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Sindh, India, and East Africa. A larger dhow may have a crew of approximately thirty while smaller dhows have crews typically ranging around twelve.[PARAGRAPH:1]Baghlahs were used as merchant ships in the Indian Ocean and the minor seas around the Arabian Peninsula. They reached eastwards up to the Bay of Bengal and the Spice Islands and southwestwards down to the East African coast.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A baghlah is a large deep-sea dhow, a traditional Arabic sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Sindh, India, and East Africa. A larger dhow may have a crew of approximately thirty while smaller dhows have crews typically ranging around twelve.[PARAGRAPH:1]Baghlahs were used as merchant ships in the Indian Ocean and the minor seas around the Arabian Peninsula. They reached eastwards up to the Bay of Bengal and the Spice Islands and southwestwards down to the East African coast.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Bagalla ist eine große Tiefsee-Dau, ein traditionelles arabisches Segelschiff mit einem oder mehreren lateinischen Segeln. Es wird hauptsächlich an den Küsten der Arabischen Halbinsel, Sindhs, Indiens und Ostafrikas eingesetzt. Eine größere Dhau kann eine Besatzung von etwa dreißig Mann haben, während kleinere Dhaus eine Besatzung von typischerweise etwa zwölf Personen haben.[PARAGRAPH:1]Baghlahs wurden als Handelsschiffe im Indischen Ozean und den kleineren Meeren rund um die Arabische Halbinsel eingesetzt. Sie reichten nach Osten bis zum Golf von Bengalen und den Gewürzinseln und nach Südwesten bis zur ostafrikanischen Küste.

A larger dhow may have a crew of approximately thirty while smaller dhows have crews typically ranging around twelve.[PARAGRAPH:1]Baghlahs were used as merchant ships in the Indian Ocean and the minor seas around the Arabian Peninsula. They reached eastwards up to the Bay of Bengal and the Spice Islands and southwestwards down to the East African coast.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A baghlah is a large deep-sea dhow, a traditional Arabic sailing vessel with one or more lateen sails. It is primarily used along the coasts of the Arabian Peninsula, Sindh, India, and East Africa. A larger dhow may have a crew of approximately thirty while smaller dhows have crews typically ranging around twelve.[PARAGRAPH:1]Baghlahs were used as merchant ships in the Indian Ocean and the minor seas around the Arabian Peninsula. They reached eastwards up to the Bay of Bengal and the Spice Islands and southwestwards down to the East African coast.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Kshatriya meaning warrior is one of the four varnas (social orders) in Hinduism. It traditionally constituted the military and ruling elite of the Vedic-Hindu social system outlined by the Vedas and the Laws of Manu.[PARAGRAPH:1]Initially in ancient Vedic society, this position was achieved on the merits of a person's aptitude, conduct, and nature. The earliest Vedic literature listed by organization of function, not of caste, the Kshatriya (holders of kshatra, or authority) as first in rank, and the Brahmins second (priests and teachers of law), before the Vaisya (merchant-traders, farmers and some artisan castes), and the Sudra (labourers, some farming castes and other artisan castes). Movements of individuals and groups from one class to another, both upward and downward, were not uncommon; a rise in status even to the rank of Kshatriya was a recognized reward for outstanding service to the rulers of the day. Over the years it became hereditary. In modern times, the Kshatriya varna includes a broad class of caste groups, differing considerably in status and function but united by their claims to ruler-ship, the pursuit of war, or the possession of land. [PARAGRAPH:1]Western India remained a stronghold of Kshatriya clans as epitomized by Rajputana and the powerful Kshatriya empire that ruled from Ujjain right up to the Islamic incursions led to a downfall of the Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi.

[PARAGRAPH:1]Western India remained a stronghold of Kshatriya clans as epitomized by Rajputana and the powerful Kshatriya empire that ruled from Ujjain right up to the Islamic incursions led to a downfall of the Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Kshatriya bedeutet Krieger und ist eine der vier Varnas (Gesellschaftsordnungen) im Hinduismus. Sie bildete traditionell die militärische und herrschende Elite des vedisch-hinduistischen Gesellschaftssystems, das in den Veden und den Gesetzen des Manu dargelegt wird.[PARAGRAPH:1]Anfangs wurde diese Position in der alten vedischen Gesellschaft auf der Grundlage der Fähigkeiten, des Verhaltens und der Fähigkeiten einer Person erreicht. und Natur. In der frühesten vedischen Literatur sind die Kshatriya (Inhaber von Kshatra oder Autorität) nach Funktionsorganisation und nicht nach Kaste an erster Stelle und die Brahmanen an zweiter Stelle (Priester und Rechtslehrer) aufgeführt, vor den Vaisya (Kaufleute, Bauern). und einige Handwerkerkasten) und die Sudra (Arbeiter, einige Bauernkasten und andere Handwerkerkasten). Bewegungen von Einzelpersonen und Gruppen von einer Klasse zur anderen, sowohl nach oben als auch nach unten, waren keine Seltenheit; Eine Erhöhung des Status bis hin zum Rang eines Kshatriya war eine anerkannte Belohnung für herausragende Verdienste um die damaligen Herrscher. Im Laufe der Jahre wurde es erblich. In der Neuzeit umfasst die Kshatriya varna eine breite Klasse von Kastengruppen, die sich in Status und Funktion erheblich unterscheiden, aber durch ihren Anspruch auf Herrschaft, Krieg oder Landbesitz vereint sind. [PARAGRAPH:1]Westindien blieb eine Hochburg der Kshatriya-Clans, wie sie Rajputana verkörperte, und das mächtige Kshatriya-Reich, das von Ujjain aus herrschte, bis zu den islamischen Einfällen, die zum Sturz der Chauhan Kshatriyas in Delhi führten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Lancer is a general term for an armored, mounted cavalryman whose primary weapon is a lance. Middle Eastern heavy cavalrymen could be seen as equivalents of European knights, but weren't limited to those of noble birth. In fact, the best heavy cavalry soldiers were slaves (e.g. Ghulams, Mamluks) or freeborn professionals (e.g. Saladin's Tawashis).
TEXT.French: [TAB]Lancer is a general term for an armored, mounted cavalryman whose primary weapon is a lance. Middle Eastern heavy cavalrymen could be seen as equivalents of European knights, but weren't limited to those of noble birth. In fact, the best heavy cavalry soldiers were slaves (e.g. Ghulams, Mamluks) or freeborn professionals (e.g. Saladin's Tawashis).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Lanzierer ist eine allgemeine Bezeichnung für einen gepanzerten, berittenen Kavalleristen, dessen Hauptwaffe eine Lanze ist. Schwere Kavalleristen aus dem Nahen Osten konnten als Äquivalente europäischer Ritter angesehen werden, waren aber nicht auf Ritter adliger Herkunft beschränkt. Tatsächlich waren die besten Soldaten der schweren Kavallerie Sklaven (z. B. Ghulams, Mamluken) oder freigeborene Berufssoldaten (z. B. Saladins Tawashis).

TEXT.English: [TAB]The tawashi were free-born cavalry troops of the Ayyubid period. Originally the Sultanate's elite horsemen, they were gradually replaced by the Mamluks.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The tawashi were free-born cavalry troops of the Ayyubid period. Originally the Sultanate's elite horsemen, they were gradually replaced by the Mamluks.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Tawashi waren freigeborene Kavallerietruppen der Ayyubid-Zeit. Ursprünglich waren sie die Elitereiter des Sultanats und wurden nach und nach durch die Mamluken ersetzt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Arabs had taken Egypt in 641, and the jihad soon turned south. Makuria was one of the few states in the world to effectively resist Muslim conquest. Makurians defeated an Arab army at the First Battle of Dongola in in 642. They repeated this feat again in 652 at the Second Battle of Dongola. In both battles, Arab writers noted the Makurians skill with the bow.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Arabs had taken Egypt in 641, and the jihad soon turned south. Makuria was one of the few states in the world to effectively resist Muslim conquest. Makurians defeated an Arab army at the First Battle of Dongola in in 642. They repeated this feat again in 652 at the Second Battle of Dongola. In both battles, Arab writers noted the Makurians skill with the bow.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Araber hatten Ägypten im Jahr 641 eingenommen und der Dschihad wandte sich bald nach Süden. Makuria war einer der wenigen Staaten der Welt, der der muslimischen Eroberung wirksam Widerstand leistete. Die Makurianer besiegten 642 in der ersten Schlacht von Dongola eine arabische Armee. Dieses Kunststück wiederholten sie 652 in der zweiten Schlacht von Dongola erneut. In beiden Schlachten bemerkten arabische Schriftsteller die Geschicklichkeit der Makurianer im Umgang mit dem Bogen.

Makurians defeated an Arab army at the First Battle of Dongola in in 642. They repeated this feat again in 652 at the Second Battle of Dongola. In both battles, Arab writers noted the Makurians skill with the bow.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ghilman were slave-soldiers in service of Middle Eastern kings and generals. Ghilman were generally Turkish in origin, fought in bands, and demanded high pay for their services.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghilman lived celibate lives. The absence of family life and offspring was one of the reasons why the Ghilman, even when attaining power, generally failed to start dynasties or proclaim their independence. The only exception to this was the Ghaznavid dynasty of Afghanistan, which originated amongst the Turkic slave-warriors of the Samanid dynasty.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Ghilman were slave-soldiers in service of Middle Eastern kings and generals. Ghilman were generally Turkish in origin, fought in bands, and demanded high pay for their services.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghilman lived celibate lives. The absence of family life and offspring was one of the reasons why the Ghilman, even when attaining power, generally failed to start dynasties or proclaim their independence. The only exception to this was the Ghaznavid dynasty of Afghanistan, which originated amongst the Turkic slave-warriors of the Samanid dynasty.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Ghilman waren Sklavensoldaten im Dienst der Könige und Generäle des Nahen Ostens. Ghilman war im Allgemeinen türkischer Herkunft, kämpfte in Banden und verlangte einen hohen Lohn für ihre Dienste.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghilman lebte ein Leben im Zölibat. Das Fehlen von Familienleben und Nachkommenschaft war einer der Gründe, warum die Ghilman, selbst als sie an die Macht kamen, es im Allgemeinen versäumten, Dynastien zu gründen oder ihre Unabhängigkeit zu proklamieren. Die einzige Ausnahme hiervon bildete die Ghaznaviden-Dynastie in Afghanistan, die aus den türkischen Sklavenkriegern der Samaniden-Dynastie hervorging.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A caravan is a group of people traveling together, often on a trade expedition. Caravans were used mainly in desert areas and throughout the Silk Road, where traveling in groups aided in defense against bandits as well as helped to improve economies of scale in trade.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A caravan is a group of people traveling together, often on a trade expedition. Caravans were used mainly in desert areas and throughout the Silk Road, where traveling in groups aided in defense against bandits as well as helped to improve economies of scale in trade.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Karawane ist eine Gruppe von Menschen, die gemeinsam reisen, oft auf einer Handelsexpedition. Karawanen wurden hauptsächlich in Wüstengebieten und auf der gesamten Seidenstraße eingesetzt, wo das Reisen in Gruppen zur Verteidigung gegen Banditen beitrug und zu größeren Skaleneffekten im Handel beitrug.

TEXT.English: [TAB]With the advent of gunpowder, heavy armor became less and less viable. Armies were slowly re-organized into musket infantry and light cavalry troops armed with melee weapons and/or small firearms.
TEXT.French: [TAB]With the advent of gunpowder, heavy armor became less and less viable. Armies were slowly re-organized into musket infantry and light cavalry troops armed with melee weapons and/or small firearms.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Mit dem Aufkommen von Schießpulver wurden schwere Panzerungen immer weniger brauchbar. Die Armeen wurden langsam in Musketeninfanterie und leichte Kavallerietruppen umstrukturiert, die mit Nahkampfwaffen und/oder kleinen Schusswaffen bewaffnet waren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]With the advent of gunpowder, heavy armor became less and less viable. Armies were slowly re-organized into musket infantry and light cavalry troops armed with melee weapons and/or small firearms.

TEXT.English: [TAB]While not as common as archers, javelin-hurling skirmishers were used by Arabs, Berbers, Turks, Afghans, Hindus as well as Byzantines (Peltastoi) and Armenians.
TEXT.French: [TAB]While not as common as archers, javelin-hurling skirmishers were used by Arabs, Berbers, Turks, Afghans, Hindus as well as Byzantines (Peltastoi) and Armenians.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Obwohl sie nicht so verbreitet sind wie Bogenschützen, wurden Javelin(Speer)werfende Plänker von Arabern, Berbern, Türken, Afghanen, Hindus sowie Byzantinern (Peltastoi) und Armeniern eingesetzt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]It was because of Basil's distrust of the native Byzantine guardsmen, whose loyalties often shifted with fatal consequences, as well as the proven loyalty of the Varangians that led Basil to employ them as his personal bodyguards. This new force became known as the Varangian Guard. Over the years, new recruits from as far abroad as Sweden, Denmark, and Norway gave a predominantly Scandinavian cast to the organization until the late 11th century.[PARAGRAPH:1]Composed primarily of Scandinavians for the first 100 years, the guard began to see increased inclusion of Anglo-Saxons after the successful invasion of England by the Normans, the earliest written record dating to 1088. At this time a large number of Anglo-Saxons and Danes emigrated to the Byzantine Empire by way of the Mediterranean. One source has more than 5,000 of them arriving in 235 ships. Those who did not enter imperial service were settled on the Black Sea, but those who did became so vital to the Varangians that it was commonly called the Englinbarrangoi from that point. In this capacity they were able to war against the Normans under Robert Guiscard in Sicily, who unsuccessfully sought to invade the lower Balkans as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Varangians served as the personal bodyguard of the emperor, swearing an oath of loyalty to him; they had ceremonial duties as retainers and acclaimers and performed some police duties, especially with regard to cases of treason and conspiracy. Other than their fierce loyalty, the most recognizable attributes of the Varangian guard during the 11th century were their large axes and their penchant for drinking. There are countless stories of the Varangian guard either drinking in excess or being drunk. In 1103 during a visit to Constantinople, King Eric of Denmark "exhorted members of the guard to lead a more sober life and not give themselves up to drunkenness." It is not surprising, due to this Varangian vice to find a 12th century description of them as "the Emperor's wine-bags."

In 1103 during a visit to Constantinople, King Eric of Denmark "exhorted members of the guard to lead a more sober life and not give themselves up to drunkenness." It is not surprising, due to this Varangian vice to find a 12th century description of them as "the Emperor's wine-bags."
TEXT.German: [TAB]Es war Basilius' Misstrauen gegenüber den einheimischen byzantinischen Gardisten, deren Loyalität sich oft mit fatalen Folgen änderte, sowie die erwiesene Loyalität der Waräger, die Basil dazu veranlasste, sie als seine persönlichen Leibwächter einzusetzen. Diese neue Truppe wurde als Warägergarde bekannt. Im Laufe der Jahre gaben neue Rekruten aus so fernen Ländern wie Schweden, Dänemark und Norwegen der Organisation bis zum Ende des 11. Jahrhunderts eine vorwiegend skandinavische Besetzung.[PARAGRAPH:1]In den ersten 100 Jahren bestand die Wache hauptsächlich aus Skandinaviern, doch dann begann sie siehe verstärkte Einbeziehung von Angelsachsen nach der erfolgreichen Invasion Englands durch die Normannen; die früheste schriftliche Erwähnung stammt aus dem Jahr 1088. Zu dieser Zeit wanderten viele Angelsachsen und Dänen über das Mittelmeer in das Byzantinische Reich aus. Einer Quelle zufolge kamen mehr als 5.000 von ihnen auf 235 Schiffen an. Diejenigen, die nicht in den kaiserlichen Dienst traten, wurden am Schwarzen Meer angesiedelt, aber diejenigen, die es taten, wurden für die Waräger so wichtig, dass sie von da an allgemein Englinbarrangoi genannt wurden. In dieser Funktion konnten sie gegen die Normannen unter Robert Guiscard in Sizilien Krieg führen, die erfolglos versuchten, auch in den unteren Balkan einzudringen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Waräger dienten als persönliche Leibwächter des Kaisers und schworen ihm einen Treueid ihn; Sie hatten zeremonielle Aufgaben als Gefolgsleute und Beisitzer und übten einige polizeiliche Aufgaben aus, insbesondere im Hinblick auf Fälle von Hochverrat und Verschwörung. Die bekanntesten Merkmale der warägerischen Garde im 11. Jahrhundert waren neben ihrer leidenschaftlichen Loyalität ihre großen Äxte und ihre Vorliebe fürs Trinken. Es gibt unzählige Geschichten darüber, dass die warägerische Wache entweder übermäßig trank oder betrunken war. Im Jahr 1103 ermahnte König Eric von Dänemark während eines Besuchs in Konstantinopel "die Mitglieder der Garde, ein nüchterneres Leben zu führen und sich nicht der Trunkenheit hinzugeben." Aufgrund dieses warägerischen Lasters ist es nicht verwunderlich, dass sie im 12. Jahrhundert als "Weinbeutel des Kaisers" beschrieben werden.

TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]It was because of Basil's distrust of the native Byzantine guardsmen, whose loyalties often shifted with fatal consequences, as well as the proven loyalty of the Varangians that led Basil to employ them as his personal bodyguards. This new force became known as the Varangian Guard. Over the years, new recruits from as far abroad as Sweden, Denmark, and Norway gave a predominantly Scandinavian cast to the organization until the late 11th century.[PARAGRAPH:1]Composed primarily of Scandinavians for the first 100 years, the guard began to see increased inclusion of Anglo-Saxons after the successful invasion of England by the Normans, the earliest written record dating to 1088. At this time a large number of Anglo-Saxons and Danes emigrated to the Byzantine Empire by way of the Mediterranean. One source has more than 5,000 of them arriving in 235 ships. Those who did not enter imperial service were settled on the Black Sea, but those who did became so vital to the Varangians that it was commonly called the Englinbarrangoi from that point. In this capacity they were able to war against the Normans under Robert Guiscard in Sicily, who unsuccessfully sought to invade the lower Balkans as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Varangians served as the personal bodyguard of the emperor, swearing an oath of loyalty to him; they had ceremonial duties as retainers and acclaimers and performed some police duties, especially with regard to cases of treason and conspiracy. Other than their fierce loyalty, the most recognizable attributes of the Varangian guard during the 11th century were their large axes and their penchant for drinking. There are countless stories of the Varangian guard either drinking in excess or being drunk. In 1103 during a visit to Constantinople, King Eric of Denmark "exhorted members of the guard to lead a more sober life and not give themselves up to drunkenness." It is not surprising, due to this Varangian vice to find a 12th century description of them as "the Emperor's wine-bags."

TEXT.English: [TAB]During the Fatimid conquest of Egypt, the Fatimid army consisted mainly of mounted Berber troops from their homeland in Ifriqiya (central part of North Africa). The highly mobile army successfully overran Egypt, though later proved ineffective against the armies of Byzantines and Buyids/Abbasids, and had to be supplanted with Turkish ghulam cavalry and foot archers.
TEXT.French: [TAB]During the Fatimid conquest of Egypt, the Fatimid army consisted mainly of mounted Berber troops from their homeland in Ifriqiya (central part of North Africa). The highly mobile army successfully overran Egypt, though later proved ineffective against the armies of Byzantines and Buyids/Abbasids, and had to be supplanted with Turkish ghulam cavalry and foot archers.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Während der Eroberung Ägyptens durch die Fatimiden bestand die Armee der Fatimiden hauptsächlich aus berittenen Berbertruppen aus ihrem Heimatland Ifriqiya (zentraler Teil Nordafrikas). Die hochmobile Armee überrannte erfolgreich Ägypten, erwies sich jedoch später gegen die Armeen der Byzantiner und Buyiden/Abbasiden als wirkungslos und musste durch türkische Ghulam-Kavallerie und Fußbogenschützen ersetzt werden.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Although piracy had existed in the region throughout the decline of the Roman Empire, the barbarian invasions, the Muhammadan conquest and the Middle Ages, piracy became particularly flagrant in the 14th century when the native Berber dynasties were in decadence. The town of Bougie was then the most notorious pirate base. [PARAGRAPH:1]Several events influenced the growth of the pirates. The conquest of Granada by the Catholic sovereigns of Spain drove many Moors into exile. They revenged themselves by piratical attacks on the Spanish coast. They had the help of Muslim adventurers from the Levant, of whom the most successful were Hizir and Oruc, natives of Mitylene. Spain in self-defense began to conquer the coast towns of Oran, Algiers and Tunis. Oruç having fallen in battle with the Spaniards in 1518, his brother Hizir appealed to Selim, the sultan of Turkey, who sent his troops. He drove the Spaniards in 1529 from the rocky island in front of Algiers, where they had a fort, and was the founder of the Turkish power.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Obwohl es in der Region während des Niedergangs des Römischen Reiches, der Invasionen der Barbaren, der Eroberung durch Mohammedaner und im Mittelalter Piraterie gegeben hatte, wurde die Piraterie im 14. Jahrhundert, als die einheimischen Berberdynastien im Niedergang begriffen waren, besonders eklatant. Die Stadt Bougie war damals der berüchtigtste Piratenstützpunkt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mehrere Ereignisse beeinflussten das Wachstum der Piraten. Die Eroberung Granadas durch die katholischen Herrscher Spaniens trieb viele Mauren ins Exil. Sie rächten sich durch Piratenangriffe an der spanischen Küste. Sie hatten die Hilfe muslimischer Abenteurer aus der Levante, von denen Hizir und Oruc, Eingeborene aus Mitylene, die erfolgreichsten waren. Spanien begann zur Selbstverteidigung die Küstenstädte Oran, Algier und Tunis zu erobern. Nachdem Oruç 1518 im Kampf mit den Spaniern gefallen war, wandte sich sein Bruder Hizir an Selim, den Sultan der Türkei, der seine Truppen entsandte. Er vertrieb die Spanier 1529 von der Felseninsel vor Algier, wo sie eine Festung hatten, und war der Gründer der türkischen Macht.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Knights Templar was a holy order devoted to defending the fledgling crusader states founded during the First Crusade against Muslim reconquest. The king of Jerusalem allowed them to make their headquarters in the main temple of Jerusalem, from which they took their name. In exchange for this hospitality they swore allegiance to the throne of Jerusalem. They participated in several major battles and did very well; this increased their numbers substantially. Eventually their power grew to the point where they could field an army of almost 10,000 knights and still uphold their promises to garrison individual towns.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Knights Templar was a holy order devoted to defending the fledgling crusader states founded during the First Crusade against Muslim reconquest. The king of Jerusalem allowed them to make their headquarters in the main temple of Jerusalem, from which they took their name. In exchange for this hospitality they swore allegiance to the throne of Jerusalem. They participated in several major battles and did very well; this increased their numbers substantially. Eventually their power grew to the point where they could field an army of almost 10,000 knights and still uphold their promises to garrison individual towns.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Tempelritter waren ein heiliger Orden, der sich der Verteidigung der jungen Kreuzfahrerstaaten widmete, die während des Ersten Kreuzzugs gegen die muslimische Rückeroberung gegründet wurden. Der König von Jerusalem erlaubte ihnen, ihr Hauptquartier im Haupttempel von Jerusalem einzurichten, von dem sie ihren Namen erhielten. Als Gegenleistung für diese Gastfreundschaft schworen sie dem Thron Jerusalems die Treue. Sie nahmen an mehreren großen Schlachten teil und schlugen sich sehr gut; Dadurch erhöhte sich ihre Zahl erheblich. Schließlich wuchs ihre Macht so weit, dass sie eine Armee von fast 10.000 Rittern aufstellen und dennoch ihre Versprechen einhalten konnten, einzelne Städte mit Garnisonen zu besetzen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Knights Hospitaller (also known as Knights of St. John) is an organization that began as an Amalfitan hospital founded in Jerusalem in 1080 to provide care for poor and sick pilgrims to the Holy Land. After the conquest of Jerusalem in 1099 during the First Crusade it became a Catholic military order under its own charter, and was charged with the care and defense of pilgrims to the Holy Land. Following the loss of Christian territory in the Holy Land, the Order operated from Rhodes, over which it was sovereign, and later from Malta where it administered a vassal state under the Spanish viceroy of Sicily. Although this state came to an end with the ejection of the Order from Malta by Napoleon, the Order as such survived.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Knights Hospitaller (also known as Knights of St. John) is an organization that began as an Amalfitan hospital founded in Jerusalem in 1080 to provide care for poor and sick pilgrims to the Holy Land. After the conquest of Jerusalem in 1099 during the First Crusade it became a Catholic military order under its own charter, and was charged with the care and defense of pilgrims to the Holy Land. Following the loss of Christian territory in the Holy Land, the Order operated from Rhodes, over which it was sovereign, and later from Malta where it administered a vassal state under the Spanish viceroy of Sicily. Although this state came to an end with the ejection of the Order from Malta by Napoleon, the Order as such survived.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Knights Hospitaller (auch bekannt als Knights of St. John) sind eine Organisation, die als amalfitanisches Krankenhaus begann, das 1080 in Jerusalem gegründet wurde, um arme und kranke Pilger ins Heilige Land zu versorgen. Nach der Eroberung Jerusalems im Jahr 1099 während des Ersten Kreuzzugs wurde er mit einer eigenen Charta zu einem katholischen Militärorden und wurde mit der Betreuung und Verteidigung der Pilger ins Heilige Land beauftragt. Nach dem Verlust des christlichen Territoriums im Heiligen Land operierte der Orden von Rhodos aus, über das er souverän war, und später von Malta aus, wo er einen Vasallenstaat unter dem spanischen Vizekönig von Sizilien verwaltete. Obwohl dieser Staat mit der Vertreibung des Ordens aus Malta durch Napoleon endete, blieb der Orden als solcher bestehen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Hashishiyya from which the word assassin is thought to originate, was the Arabic designation of the Nizari branch of the Isma'ili Shia Muslims during the Middle Ages. The Nizariyya, or Hashishiyya, as they were designated by their enemies, split from the Fatimid Isma'ili Empire following a dispute regarding the succession of their spiritual and political leader the Fatimid Caliph Ma'ad al-Mustansir Billah. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Nizariyya formulated a strategy of gaining control of strategically important fortresses by covertly converting local inhabitants living within and around strategically vital fortresses in Isma'ili territory. They established a new type of state within a state which consisted of a number of "island" fortified settlements within a sea of hostility in present day Iran, Iraq, Syria and Lebanon. The formal origin of the Federation of the Assassins is marked as 1090 when Hassan-i Sabbah established his first stronghold in Daylam at the fortress of Alamut south of the Caspian Sea. Alamut remained the capital of the Federation of the Assassins, and the home of its rulers, styled "The Lords of Alamut," until its destruction. [PARAGRAPH:2]Unable to mount a conventional military army, the Nizariyya developed a form of asymmetric warfare transforming the act of political assassination into a system of survival and defense against their foes. They trained highly capable sleeper commandos (trained in languages, science, trade, and so on) known as Fedayeen, who would covertly infiltrate enemy positions and remain undercover. If Nizari civilians were facing pogroms or their forts faced imminent attack, the Fedayeen were activated to prevent an attack.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Hashishiyya from which the word assassin is thought to originate, was the Arabic designation of the Nizari branch of the Isma'ili Shia Muslims during the Middle Ages. The Nizariyya, or Hashishiyya, as they were designated by their enemies, split from the Fatimid Isma'ili Empire following a dispute regarding the succession of their spiritual and political leader the Fatimid Caliph Ma'ad al-Mustansir Billah. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Nizariyya formulated a strategy of gaining control of strategically important fortresses by covertly converting local inhabitants living within and around strategically vital fortresses in Isma'ili territory. They established a new type of state within a state which consisted of a number of "island" fortified settlements within a sea of hostility in present day Iran, Iraq, Syria and Lebanon. Alamut remained the capital of the Federation of the Assassins, and the home of its rulers, styled "The Lords of Alamut," until its destruction. [PARAGRAPH:2]Unable to mount a conventional military army, the Nizariyya developed a form of asymmetric warfare transforming the act of political assassination into a system of survival and defense against their foes. They trained highly capable sleeper commandos (trained in languages, science, trade, and so on) known as Fedayeen, who would covertly infiltrate enemy positions and remain undercover. If Nizari civilians were facing pogroms or their forts faced imminent attack, the Fedayeen were activated to prevent an attack.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Hashishiyya, aus dem vermutlich das Wort "Attentäter" stammt, war die arabische Bezeichnung des Nizari-Zweigs der ismailitischen schiitischen Muslime im Mittelalter. Die Nizariyya oder Hashishiyya, wie sie von ihren Feinden genannt wurden, trennten sich vom Fatimiden-Ismailien-Reich nach einem Streit über die Nachfolge ihres spirituellen und politischen Führers, des fatimidischen Kalifen Ma'ad al-Mustansir Billah. [ABSATZ:2]Die Nizariyya formulierten eine Strategie zur Erlangung der Kontrolle über strategisch wichtige Festungen durch heimliche Umsiedlung der örtlichen Bevölkerung, die innerhalb und um strategisch wichtige Festungen im ismailitischen Gebiet lebten. Sie gründeten eine neue Art von Staat innerhalb eines Staates, der aus einer Reihe befestigter "Insel"-Siedlungen inmitten eines Meeres der Feindseligkeit im heutigen Iran, Irak, Syrien und Libanon bestand. Der formelle Ursprung der Föderation der Assassinen geht auf das Jahr 1090 zurück, als Hassan-i Sabbah seine erste Festung in Daylam in der Festung Alamut südlich des Kaspischen Meeres errichtete. Alamut blieb bis zu seiner Zerstörung die Hauptstadt der Föderation der Assassinen und die Heimat ihrer Herrscher, die als "Die Herren von Alamut" bezeichnet wurden. [PARAGRAPH:2]Da die Nizariyya nicht in der Lage waren, eine konventionelle Militärarmee aufzustellen, entwickelten sie eine Form der asymmetrischen Kriegsführung, die den Akt des politischen Attentats in ein System des Überlebens und der Verteidigung gegen ihre Feinde verwandelte. Sie bildeten hochqualifizierte Schläferkommandos aus (ausgebildet in Sprachen, Wissenschaft, Handel usw.), bekannt als Fedayeen, die heimlich feindliche Stellungen infiltrierten und verdeckt blieben. Wenn Nizari-Zivilisten Pogromen ausgesetzt waren oder ihre Festungen unmittelbar angegriffen wurden, wurden die Fedayeen aktiviert, um einen Angriff zu verhindern.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Troops who fight on foot, even though transported to the battlefield by horses or ships, are classified as Infantry. This term applies equally to troops armed with weapons such as the spear, sword, and mace in ancient and medieval times. As with most foot-soldiers, the objective of the medieval Infantry was to seize and hold territory, often in an attempt to occupy enemy territory.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Troops who fight on foot, even though transported to the battlefield by horses or ships, are classified as Infantry. This term applies equally to troops armed with weapons such as the spear, sword, and mace in ancient and medieval times. As with most foot-soldiers, the objective of the medieval Infantry was to seize and hold territory, often in an attempt to occupy enemy territory.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Truppen, die zu Fuß kämpfen, auch wenn sie mit Pferden oder Schiffen zum Schlachtfeld transportiert werden, werden als Infanterie klassifiziert. Dieser Begriff gilt gleichermaßen für Truppen, die in der Antike und im Mittelalter mit Waffen wie Speer, Schwert und Streitkolben bewaffnet waren. Wie bei den meisten Fußsoldaten bestand das Ziel der mittelalterlichen Infanterie darin, Gebiete zu erobern und zu halten, oft in dem Versuch, feindliches Gebiet zu besetzen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Troops who fight on foot, even though transported to the battlefield by horses or ships, are classified as Infantry. TEXT.English: [TAB]Naffatun were Arabian infantry corps armed with naphtha grenades. They are noted for the successful defense during the Seljuk Siege of Baghdad in 1157, when they managed to destroy several catapults.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Naffatun were Arabian infantry corps armed with naphtha grenades. They are noted for the successful defense during the Seljuk Siege of Baghdad in 1157, when they managed to destroy several catapults.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Naffatun waren arabische Infanteriekorps, die mit Naphtha-Granaten bewaffnet waren. Sie sind bekannt für ihre erfolgreiche Verteidigung während der Seldschuken-Belagerung von Bagdad im Jahr 1157, bei der es ihnen gelang, mehrere Katapulte zu zerstören.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Naffatun were Arabian infantry corps armed with naphtha grenades. They are noted for the successful defense during the Seljuk Siege of Baghdad in 1157, when they managed to destroy several catapults.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Naffatun were Arabian infantry corps armed with naphtha grenades. They are noted for the successful defense during the Seljuk Siege of Baghdad in 1157, when they managed to destroy several catapults.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Daylamites were Iranian people inhabiting the mountainous regions of northern Iran on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. They were employed as soldiers from the time of the Sassanid Empire, and long resisted the Arab conquest of Iran and subsequent Islamization.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Daylamites were Iranian people inhabiting the mountainous regions of northern Iran on the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. They were employed as soldiers from the time of the Sassanid Empire, and long resisted the Arab conquest of Iran and subsequent Islamization.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Dailamiten waren ein iranisches Volk, das in den Bergregionen im Norden Irans an der Südküste des Kaspischen Meeres lebte. Sie wurden seit der Zeit des Sassanidenreichs als Soldaten eingesetzt und leisteten lange Zeit Widerstand gegen die arabische Eroberung Irans und die anschließende Islamisierung.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Lancer is a general term for an armored, mounted cavalryman whose primary weapon is a lance. Middle Eastern heavy cavalrymen could be seen as equivalents of European knights, but weren't limited to those of noble birth. In fact, the best heavy cavalry soldiers were slaves (e.g. Ghulams, Mamluks) or freeborn professionals (e.g. Saladin's Tawashis).
TEXT.French: [TAB]Lancer is a general term for an armored, mounted cavalryman whose primary weapon is a lance. Middle Eastern heavy cavalrymen could be seen as equivalents of European knights, but weren't limited to those of noble birth. In fact, the best heavy cavalry soldiers were slaves (e.g. Ghulams, Mamluks) or freeborn professionals (e.g. Saladin's Tawashis).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Lanzierer ist eine allgemeine Bezeichnung für einen gepanzerten, berittenen Kavalleristen, dessen Hauptwaffe eine Lanze ist. Schwere Kavalleristen aus dem Nahen Osten konnten als Äquivalente europäischer Ritter angesehen werden, waren aber nicht auf Ritter adliger Herkunft beschränkt. Tatsächlich waren die besten Soldaten der schweren Kavallerie Sklaven (z. B. Ghulams, Mamluken) oder freigeborene Berufssoldaten (z. B. Saladins Tawashis).

TEXT.English: [TAB]Unlike in Europe, the best cavalry soldiers in the Middle East were not necessarily feudal lords but professionals, e.g. slave-warriors. Nevertheless, horsemen drawn from the nobility could be a valuable asset in times of war.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Unlike in Europe, the best cavalry soldiers in the Middle East were not necessarily feudal lords but professionals, e.g. slave-warriors. Nevertheless, horsemen drawn from the nobility could be a valuable asset in times of war.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Anders als in Europa waren die besten Kavalleriesoldaten im Nahen Osten nicht unbedingt Feudalherren, sondern Profis, z.B. Sklavenkrieger. Dennoch könnten Reiter aus dem Adel in Kriegszeiten eine wertvolle Bereicherung sein.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A mamluk was a slave soldier who converted to Islam and served the Muslim Arab caliphs from the 9th to the 16th centuries.Over time, they became a powerful military caste often defeating the Crusaders. On more than one occasion, they seized power for themselves; for example, ruling Egypt in the Mamluk Dynasty from 1250-1517. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluks were raised as cavalry soldiers and through rigorous training achieved mastery in cavalry tactics, horsemanship and mounted combat. One of the most impressive achievements of the mamluk heavy cavalry was the victory over the previously unmatched Mongol light cavalry in the Battle of Ain Jalut. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluk dominance on the battlefield ended with the emergence of gunpowder weapons. Unlike their enemies, the Ottomans, Mamluks relied too much on cavalry charge and were incapable of making good use of the arquebus and the cannon.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A mamluk was a slave soldier who converted to Islam and served the Muslim Arab caliphs from the 9th to the 16th centuries.Over time, they became a powerful military caste often defeating the Crusaders. On more than one occasion, they seized power for themselves; for example, ruling Egypt in the Mamluk Dynasty from 1250-1517. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluks were raised as cavalry soldiers and through rigorous training achieved mastery in cavalry tactics, horsemanship and mounted combat. One of the most impressive achievements of the mamluk heavy cavalry was the victory over the previously unmatched Mongol light cavalry in the Battle of Ain Jalut. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluk dominance on the battlefield ended with the emergence of gunpowder weapons. Unlike their enemies, the Ottomans, Mamluks relied too much on cavalry charge and were incapable of making good use of the arquebus and the cannon.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Mamluk war ein Sklavensoldat, der zum Islam konvertierte und vom 9. bis 16. Jahrhundert den muslimisch-arabischen Kalifen diente. Mit der Zeit entwickelten sie sich zu einer mächtigen Militärkaste, die oft die Kreuzfahrer besiegte. Mehr als einmal ergriffen sie die Macht; zum Beispiel regierte er Ägypten in der Mamluken-Dynastie von 1250-1517. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mameluken wurden als Kavalleriesoldaten erzogen und erlangten durch strenge Ausbildung Meisterschaften in Kavallerietaktiken, Reitkünsten und berittenen Kämpfen. Eine der beeindruckendsten Errungenschaften der mamlukischen schweren Kavallerie war der Sieg über die bisher unübertroffene leichte mongolische Kavallerie in der Schlacht von Ain Jalut. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Dominanz der Mamluken auf dem Schlachtfeld endete mit dem Aufkommen von Schießpulverwaffen. Im Gegensatz zu ihren Feinden, den Osmanen, verließen sich die Mamluken zu sehr auf den Angriff der Kavallerie und waren nicht in der Lage, die Arkebuse und die Kanone sinnvoll einzusetzen.

On more than one occasion, they seized power for themselves; for example, ruling Egypt in the Mamluk Dynasty from 1250-1517. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluks were raised as cavalry soldiers and through rigorous training achieved mastery in cavalry tactics, horsemanship and mounted combat. One of the most impressive achievements of the mamluk heavy cavalry was the victory over the previously unmatched Mongol light cavalry in the Battle of Ain Jalut. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluk dominance on the battlefield ended with the emergence of gunpowder weapons. Unlike their enemies, the Ottomans, Mamluks relied too much on cavalry charge and were incapable of making good use of the arquebus and the cannon.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Horseman represents various light cavalry regiments. Inferior to other mounted units, it may be the only option for non-nomadic states that cannot afford to field armored lancers or slave cavalry.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Horseman represents various light cavalry regiments. Inferior to other mounted units, it may be the only option for non-nomadic states that cannot afford to field armored lancers or slave cavalry.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Reiter repräsentiert verschiedene leichte Kavallerieregimenter. Da es anderen berittenen Einheiten unterlegen ist, ist es möglicherweise die einzige Option für nicht-nomadische Staaten, die es sich nicht leisten können, gepanzerte Lanzenreiter oder Sklavenkavallerie aufzustellen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Spears were arguably one of the most common personal weapons from the late Bronze Age until the advent of firearms. They may be seen as the ancestor of such weapons as the lance, the halberd and the pike.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Spears were arguably one of the most common personal weapons from the late Bronze Age until the advent of firearms. They may be seen as the ancestor of such weapons as the lance, the halberd and the pike.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Speere waren wohl eine der häufigsten persönlichen Waffen von der späten Bronzezeit bis zum Aufkommen von Schusswaffen. Sie können als Vorfahren von Waffen wie der Lanze, der Hellebarde und dem Hecht angesehen werden.
